problem_text: Given an infinite set Ω, define an algebra A (the reduced incidence algebra of finite subsets) as follows. Let Vn be the set of functions from the set of n-element subsets of Ω to the rationals Q. Now let A = ⊕ Vn, with multiplication as follows: for f ∈ Vn, g ∈ Vm, and |X| = m + n, let (fg)(X) = ∑ f(Y)g(X \ Y), where the sum is over the n-element subsets Y of X. If G is a permutation group on Ω, let AG be the algebra of G-invariants in A. Conjecture: If G has no finite orbits on Ω, then AG is an integral domain. P. J. Cameron
answer: Conjecture is proved (M. Pouzet, Theor. Inf. App., 42, no. 1 (2008), 83–103).
